head.title: News | SpaceX

body.class: html not-front not-logged-in no-sidebars page-news page-news-rssxml section-news page-views page-

li.class: menu__item is-leaf first leaf menu-422 falcon
menu__item is-leaf last leaf menu-9551 starship
menu__item is-active-trail is-leaf first leaf active-trail menu-9561 updates
menu__item is-leaf last leaf menu-430 shop

a.title: Shop for official SpaceX gear and accessories.

div.p: On Sunday, January 19, SpaceX successfully completed an in-flight test of Crew Dragonâs launch escape capabilities from Launch Complex 39A (LC-39A) at NASAâs Kennedy Space Center in Florida.
Packed with about 3,800 pounds of cargo and science, SpaceXâs Dragon spacecraft departed the International Space Station on Tuesday, January 7.

On Monday, January 6 at 9:19 p.m. EST, or 2:19 UTC on January 7, SpaceX launched its third launch of Starlink satellites from Space Launch Complex 40 (SLC-40) at Cape Canaveral Air Force Station, Florida.

On Monday, December 16 at 7:10 p.m. EST, SpaceX launched JCSAT-18/Kacific1 from Space Launch Complex 40 (SLC-40) at Cape Canaveral Air Force Station, Florida. The satellite was deployed approximately 33 minutes after liftoff.

h2.a: DRAGON ARRIVES AT THE INTERNATIONAL SPACE STATION

div.p: Dragon arrived at the International Space Station on December 8, 2019 and was captured at 2:05 a.m. PDT while flying over 250 statute miles over the South Pacific.

On Thursday, December 5, SpaceX launched its nineteenth Commercial Resupply Services mission (CRS-19) at 12:29 p.m. EST, or 17:29 UTC, from Space Launch Complex 40 (SLC-40) at Cape Canaveral Air Force Station, Florida.
On Monday, November 11 at 9:56 a.m. EST, 14:56 UTC, SpaceX launched 60 Starlink satellites from Space Launch Complex 40 (SLC-40) at Cape Canaveral Air Force Station, Florida.

SpaceX's Starship and Super Heavy launch vehicle is a fully, rapidly reusable transportation system designed to carry both crew and cargo to Earth orbit, the Moon, Mars, and anywhere else in the solar system.
Packed with about 3,300 pounds of cargo and science, SpaceXâs Dragon spacecraft departed the International Space Station on Tuesday, August 27.
